Definition: The process by which an atom or a molecule acquires a negative or positive charge by gaining or losing electrons.
A device in a mass spectrometer that separates ions according to their mass-to-charge ratios.
A component of a mass spectrometer that records the charge-induced signal from ions.
A technique where ions are subjected to two or more stages of mass analysis.
A technique used in mass spectrometry to produce ions using an electrospray.
A soft ionization technique used in mass spectrometry, allowing the analysis of biomolecules and large organic molecules.
A type of mass analyzer that uses oscillating electric fields to filter ions by their mass-to-charge ratio.
A mass spectrometry technique where ions are separated by their time of flight, which correlates with their mass-to-charge ratio.
A type of mass analyzer that uses an orbital trapping field to achieve high resolution and mass accuracy.
A high-resolution technique used to determine the mass-to-charge ratio of ions based on their cyclotron frequency.
The process by which ions break into smaller pieces, which can be analyzed to determine structural information.
The peak in a mass spectrum that has the greatest intensity.
A plot that represents the distribution of ions by mass-to-charge ratio in a sample.
A dimensionless quantity that represents the mass of an ion divided by its charge.
The distribution of isotopes in the mass spectrum of an element or molecule.
